The selective hydrogenation of stearic acid to produce stearyl alcohol at 300 °C and 50 bar pressure was studied over a series of cobalt alumina catalysts with different cobalt loadings. Catalysts were prepared by wet impregnation and characterised by X-ray diffraction, H2 temperature programmed reduction, H2 chemisorption, N2 adsorption-desorption and Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy. Stearyl alcohol was observed to be the main reaction product, although heptadecane, octadecane and stearyl stearate were also produced in lesser amounts. The product selectivity was influenced by the availability of Lewis acid sites on the support which were found to be responsible for ester formation. Increasing the cobalt loading diminished the number of acid sites on the support surface whilst increasing the number of cobalt metal sites and thus enhanced the relative rate of hydrogenation leading to improved selectivity to stearyl alcohol. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Cobalt Alumina Stearic acid Hydrogenation Stearyl alcohol Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Fatty alcohols (i.e., long chain primary alcohols) are a key type of oleochemical which have an extensive range of applications including fragrances, detergents, cosmetic products, plasticizers, emulsifiers, lubricants, health supplements and pharmaceuticals [1–3]. These compounds are also key intermediates for many other important chemicals (e.g. fatty alcohol ethoxylates, metal alkoxides and alkyl halides) [4–6]. Aside from widespread applicability, the significance of fatty alcohols is also inferred by ever increasing global demand that reached 3.9 million tonnes in 2022 [7]. The growth within this sector is at least partly related to the Covid-19 pandemic since fatty alcohols are used in sanitizers, detergents and soaps [7]. Fatty alcohols can be derived from natural oils via direct hydrogenation over a supported metal catalyst. However, high hydrogen consumption and harsh reaction condition make this process undesirable from an economic point of view. This issue can be addressed by using natural oil derivatives such as fatty acids, fatty acid methyl esters or even wax esters as the feedstock instead of the natural oil itself [1,10,11]. A simple fatty acid like stearic acid (C18H36O2) may be adopted as a model compound to study the mechanism/reaction scheme since stearic acid is a saturated fatty acid that is present in almost all natural oils [1]. The reaction pathway for fatty acid hydrogenation is known to be comprised of several steps (see Scheme 1) with hydrodeoxygenation generally viewed as the dominant pathway and decarboxylation/decarbonylation as a side reaction. The extent to which the three different pathways occur is strongly influenced by the catalyst and reaction pressure/temperature [8]. The main challenge for fatty alcohol production from a fatty acid is maintaining selectivity at high conversion. Over-hydrogenation, decarboxylation/decarbonylation and esterification occur more readily under these conditions resulting in higher selectivity to undesired by-products [9,10]. This challenge can be resolved by employing a catalyst with particular characteristics that hinder the side reactions. In addition to high selectivity, an effective catalyst should be stable (i.e., acid resistant, not easily poisoned, low activity towards saponification) and be active under as mild a reaction condition as possible [1]. Commercially, fatty alcohol production is carried out at elevated temperature (200–300 °C) and pressure (100–300 bar) over Cu-Cr based catalysts [12–17]. These reaction condition are far from ideal and the use of a Cr-based formulation leads to environmental concerns [2]. As a result of these limitations, many studies have been devoted to investigating alternative catalytic metals. Platinum is one of the most widely used hydrogenation catalysts due to high activity and hydrogen dissociation capability. For instance, Manyar et al. explored Pt/TiO2 catalysts for the hydrogenation of stearic acid at 130 °C and 20 bar H2 pressure [11]. Complete conversion was achieved after 20 h with 93% fatty alcohol selectivity and 7% selectivity to alkanes. The role of rhenium as a promoter was also investigated but this generally enhanced activity at the expense of stearyl alcohol selectivity. Palladium-based catalysts have also been tested in the hydrogenation of stearic acid. Silica supported Pd-Re was tested by Takeda et al. [12], who found the optimum Re:Pd ratio was 8. Tests conducted at 140 °C and 80 bar H2 pressure resulted in 96.6% stearyl alcohol selectivity at 45.3% conversion after 4 h. The application of platinum, palladium and other noble metals have also been reported in other studies [13–15]. The high price of noble metals has meant research has shifted towards cheaper and more abundant transition metal catalysts [16]. Indeed, nickel and cobalt metals are widely employed as hydrogenation catalysts to produce green diesel where fatty alcohols are intermediates (i.e., deliberate formation of alkane products in Scheme 1) [17–25]. More specifically, cobalt catalysts are well known for their activity in hydrodeoxygenation instead of decarboxylation/decarbonylation [20,21,24,26,27]. If excess hydrogenation can be avoided then cobalt can be a promising metal for fatty alcohol production. Zhou et. al reported that the application of Co/ZrO2 catalyst produced fatty alcohol in a 85.7% yield [28]. This high yield was obtained by lowering reaction temperature and increasing hydrogen pressure to limit over-hydrogenation as has been reported elsewhere [28–33,34]. It is worth noting that Co/Al2O3 catalysts have been used previously for catalytic upgrading of natural oil (and its derivatives) to alkanes with fatty alcohols as an intermediate product [21,26,35,36]. In this study, the activity of cobalt supported alumina for the hydrogenation of stearic acid was investigated with the objective of optimising fatty alcohol formation. Whilst Co was inherently selective to the desired alcohol under the reaction conditions employed, other products (alkanes & esters) were formed. Ester formation was found to be linked with Lewis acidity on the support and this reaction pathway could be conveniently controlled by increasing Co loading since this decreased the amount of surface acidity. Thus, higher loaded Co/Al2O3 catalysts allowed for the stoichiometric conversion of stearic acid to stearyl alcohol. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (> 98%), stearic acid (> 98.5%), stearyl alcohol (99%) and stearyl stearate (> 98%) were purchased from Sigma Aldrich. Alumina was obtained from Degussa/Evonik (Aeroxide-Alu C, 99 m2 g−1). Toluene was obtained from Merck (99.9%). All chemicals were used as received. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Cobalt supported alumina catalysts were prepared by wetness impregnation. To prepare 2% Co/Al2O3, 4.9 g of alumina was suspended in 50 ml of deionised water while stirring. An aqueous solution (10 ml) containing 0.49 g of cobalt nitrate hexahydrate was added dropwise to the alumina slurry and the mixture was left to stir for 12 h. The mixture was then dried for 12 h on a rotary evaporator before being calcined for 5 h at 500 °C. By altering the amount of cobalt nitrate added, the same procedure was also used to prepare samples with 4, 6, 8 and 10 wt% cobalt loadings. 2.3 Catalyst characterisation Surface area, pore volume and pore size distributions were measured by nitrogen adsorption using a Micromeritics Tristar instrument. Before each measurement, samples were degassed for 2 h at 200 °C in a flow of nitrogen. Surface area was calculated from the BET method while the pore volume and pore diameter were determined by the BJH method. Powder X-Ray Diffraction (XRD) patterns of calcined samples were collected using an X′Pert Powder diffractometer supplied by PANalytical using Cu Kα radiation. The patterns were collected at 40 kV and 40 mA and with a step size of 0.05° in the range 10–70° 2θ. In order to investigate the reducibility, H2 Temperature Programmed Reduction (TPR) experiments were performed using a TPDRO 1100 instrument with a TCD detector. For analysis, approximately 80 mg of catalyst was placed in a quartz reactor tube between quartz wool plugs. A mixture of 5% H2/N2 was passed through the sample while heating to 900 °C at 10 °C min−1. Hydrogen consumption was quantified based on a response factor determined from reduction of a high purity CuO standard. The degree of reduction at fixed temperature (400 °C) was measured by gravimetric analysis using a CI Precision MK2-G1 microbalance attached to a glass vacuum line. Note: the degree of reduction gives insight into the amount of Co which is reducible at a specific temperature (i.e., this gives insight into the surface/near surface region reduction). The degree of reduction is therefore influenced by both metal loading and metal particle size/dispersion. As such, there is not necessarily a simple correlation between degree of reduction and Co metal surface area. However, it does give insight into reduction under the conditions used prior to catalytic tests (see below). For this measurement, about 100 mg of sample was loaded into a sample bucket and heated to 400 °C under vacuum. Once the mass had stabilised (ca. 150 min), a gas flow of pure H2 was introduced and maintained for 4 h. The difference in sample mass before and after the 4 h time period was used to calculate moles of oxygen lost. The degree of reduction was calculated using the expression below where the ‘initial moles of oxygen in sample’ were assumed based on the Co phase originating as Co3O4: (1) Degree of reduction = Moles of oxygen lost Initial moles of oxygen in sample Hydrogen chemisorption/uptake for reduced samples were measured using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020-C instrument. Samples were first reduced in situ (4 h, 400 °C, H2 flow) before being evacuated and cooled to 35 °C. Samples were then exposed to ever increasing H2 overpressures (1–400 torr) to produce an adsorption isotherm. The collected data was fitted to the Langmuir adsorption isotherm to determine the monolayer coverage. In order to measure the dispersion, it was assumed that dissociative adsorption occurred and that the adsorption stoichiometry was one atom of cobalt to one atom of hydrogen. The cobalt particle size after reduction was estimated using the procedure of Reuel and Bartholomew, [37] using the following expression: (2) d = C 1 ⁄ % D Where d is the particle diameter (nm), C1 is a constant associated with planar area of a cobalt atom based on density, atomic weight and the three most common crystallographic planes. %D is the percentage dispersion as calculated according to Eq. (3): (3) % D = C 2 X ⁄ W . f Where C2 is a constant for cobalt based on the stoichiometry of hydrogen on cobalt surface sites, X is the hydrogen uptake (based on H2 chemisorption data), W is metal loading and f is the degree of reduction of cobalt for a given sample (based on gravimetric analysis). The cobalt content in fresh and used catalysts was determined using an Agilent 4100 Microwave Plasma Atomic Emission Spectrometer (MP-AES). Prior to analysis, samples were digested in aqua regia and diluted in distilled water. The instrument was calibrated using standards prepared from cobalt nitrate. The acidity of catalysts was assessed by pyridine adsorption using in-situ Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy. Samples were first pressed in self-supporting 16 mm discs and placed into a quartz sample holder. The sample holder was placed into a quartz cell attached to a conventional vacuum line which permitted pre-treatment, exposure to pyridine and post-treatments. Pre-treatment consisted of evacuation, heating to 400 °C and reduction at that temperature for 4 h. The cell was subsequently cooled and evacuated at room temperature. Sample was exposed to pyridine and after 10 mins a spectrum was collected using a Perkin Elmer Spectrum 100 instrument with a liquid nitrogen cooled Mercury Cadmium Telluride (MCT) detector. Further spectra were collected in turn after evacuation at room temperature, 100 °C and 160 °C. In terms of spectral analysis, the band at 1450 cm−1 uniquely represents pyridine bound at Lewis acid sites. Therefore, based on the integration of this band and the corresponding molar absorption coefficient, the amount of pyridine retained could be calculated from Eq. (4): (4) n T = A L C d ε L m where nT is the total number of micromoles of pyridine adsorbed per gram of sample, AL is the integrated peak area of the adsorption band at 1450 cm−1, Cd is the cross-sectional area of the sample disc (cm2), m is sample disc mass (g) and ε L is the molar absorption coefficient (cm µmol−1) taken from a previous study [38]. 2.4 Catalyst activity test Hydrogenation of stearic acid was carried out in a stainless-steel autoclave reactor (Ken Kimble, 300 ml) equipped with a magnetic coupling that allowed for external overhead stirring (Heidolph RZR1). The reactor was heated using a band heater (Omega, 850 W, 240 V) and a variable autotransformer to regulate voltage/temperature. Prior to each reaction, catalyst samples were reduced ex-situ under a flow of H2 at 400 °C for 4 h before the desired mass was transferred to the reactor which was pre-charged with 500 mg of stearic acid and 50 ml of toluene as solvent (Note: toluene was selected as solvent since it offers higher substrate solubility than an alkane such as n-hexane. Under the reaction conditions used toluene shows some reactivity and this aspect is discussed within the manuscript). The reactor was subsequently sealed, purged, pressurised and heated to 300 °C. Reactions were conducted at 50 bar H2 pressure and stirred at 500 rpm. After the allotted time period, the reactor was allowed to cool before being depressurized and the liquid phase collected for analysis after catalyst filtration. In order to help elucidate reaction pathways, additional reactions were performed using 250 mg of stearyl stearate instead of stearic acid (conditions were otherwise the same). In order to study decarboxylation, stearic acid was reacted in the absence of H2 but under a N2 atmosphere (4 bar pressure). 2.5 Product analysis Reaction products (stearyl alcohol, stearyl stearate, octadecanal, octadecane and heptadecane) were identified using an Agilent 5977 GC-MS fitted with a capillary column (HP-5, 30 m x 0.25 mm × 0.25 µm). Products were analysed directly without chemical derivatization but using a split ratio of 50:1. Quantitative analysis was performed using a Varian 3800 GC-FID fitted with another capillary column (ZB FFAP, 30 m x 0.25 mm × 0.25 µm). Again, products were analysed without chemical derivatization but this time using a split ratio of 30:1. Response factors were determined by analysing samples of known concentration prepared from samples of known purity. % Conversion, % selectivity and product yield were calculated from the following equations: (5) % Conversion : X = n i − n f n i × 100 (6) % Selectivity : S = n p n i − n f × 100 (7) Product yield = X × S Where ni is the initial number of moles of reactant, nf is the number of moles of reactant left after reaction and np is the number of moles of a given product formed. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterisation A series of Co/Al2O3 catalysts were prepared with cobalt weight loading varying stepwise from 2 to 10 wt%. The textural properties of the series (surface area and pore volume) are summarised in Table 1. All samples presented a type IV isotherm shape (see Fig. S1 in supporting information) with a characteristic hysteresis loop associated with capillary condensation within mesopores [39]. The parent alumina possessed a surface area of 99 m2 g−1 and all Co containing samples showed a deceased surface area. The decrease became more pronounced with higher Co loadings and occurred with a reduction in the total pore volume which may be indicative of a degree of pore blocking. The metal loading of the 4 wt% Co/Al2O3 sample was analysed by MP-AES to verify that the actual loading was similar to the nominal loading (4.03 wt% measured vs 4.0 wt% nominal). XRD patterns ( Fig. 1) of all catalysts show peaks at ca. 32, 35, 39, 45 and 67° 2θ which may be attributed to the gamma alumina support. Additional peaks are observed at 18.9 and 36.9° 2θ are assigned to the (111) and (311) crystallographic planes of Co3O4 [26,40–44] with these peaks generally becoming more apparent as Co loading increases. Further peaks associated with the Co3O4 phase can be observed at 31.4, 44.9, 59.5 and 65.3° 2θ although are only really apparent at higher Co loading. It should be noted that the peak at 36.9° 2θ is also consistent with the presence of a cobalt aluminate (CoAl2O4) which has the same spinel structure [40]. The existence of the aluminate phase is likely to hinder sample reduction (see later). H2-TPR was carried out to access the relative reducibility of cobalt in the samples as a function of metal loading ( Fig. 2). Profiles display three main reduction features which represent the stepwise reduction of Co3O4 to Co0 and are in agreement with previous studies [21,45–47]. The first sharp feature at around 350 °C is assigned to reduction of Co3O4 to CoO and the broad feature extending from about 470–750 °C is associated with the reduction of CoO to Co0. If these two steps occur sequentially then the ratio of the second peak integral relative to first peak should be 3:1 based on stoichiometry. In this study, the ratio of the second peak to the first varies between 2.4 and 3.1. A ratio of less than 3 may imply that reduction of CoO may occur concurrently before all of the Co3O4 has been converted to CoO. Indeed, previous studies with Co/Al2O3 and Co/SiO2 samples using combined TPR-EXAFS/XANES confirmed that the reduction of CoO to Co0 started below 400 °C while reduction of Co3O4 to CoO was still proceeding [47]. The reduction feature at higher temperature (beginning at approximately 750 °C) suggests the existence of Co species with stronger metal-support interactions or the presence of cobalt-aluminate. The later explanation would lend credence to the possible existence of a spinel phase which could not be ruled out by XRD. From TPR data the overall extent of reduction was calculated based on the combined integrals of all features in the TPR profiles (Table 1 – TPR reducibility). In general, a higher extent of reduction occurs as metal loading increased. The dispersion of metallic cobalt was determined from H2 chemisorption after factoring in the degree of reduction at 400 °C from gravimetric analysis (see Table 1). Note, this temperature was selected to replicate the pre-treatment employed for catalysts used in reaction. The 2 wt% sample showed a low signal to noise ratio on the gravimetric apparatus meaning that it was not possible to ascertain the degree of reduction. The degree of reduction results shows a range of values between 18% and 32% which do not necessarily correlate with the TPR reproducibility. For example, 10 wt% sample showed the lowest degree of reduction (18.2%) despite the highest TPR reducibility (79%). 4–10 wt% samples were analysed by H2 chemisorption following reduction at 400 °C with results also shown in Table 1. As expected, a progressive increase in H2 uptake with increasing metal loading was observed and this may be a good indicator of the amount of zero valent Co sites present in a given sample. From here, metal dispersion and particle size were estimated. For all samples, the metal dispersion was relatively small (5.0–7.3%) which resulted in particle sizes in the range 13–19 nm which broadly correlates with metal loading. 3.2 Hydrogenation of stearic acid In this study, stearic acid was selected as a model fatty acid [48,49] because it does not contain any CC double bonds meaning that there is no competition between hydrogenation of the different functional groups (i.e., carboxylate vs alkene). This is important since the enthalpy required to break a CC bond (614 kJ mol−1) is lower than a CO bond (799 kJ mol−1) which means that hydrogenation of the CC bond normally occurs prior to deoxygenation [4]. The effect of reaction time on the hydrogenation of stearic acid over 4% Co/Al2O3 as an example is illustrated in Fig. 3 (reaction conditions: 300 °C and 50 bar H2). This plot was constructed from analysis of 5 individual reactions. Whilst every reaction was not performed in duplicate, select reactions were repeated if a data point seemed to lie out with the general trend. Fig. 3 shows that conversion increased to ca. 33% up until a 15 h reaction time. For longer reactions only a minor increase in conversion was observed (1–2%) despite extending the reaction time to 48 h. Build-up of product/s on the surface and subsequent inhibition may explain the trend in stearic acid conversion after 15 h time. Other potential explanations include the reaction reaching equilibrium under the conditions selected or catalyst deactivation due to cobalt leaching. These issues were all assessed and are addressed later. Stearyl alcohol, octadecane and stearyl stearate were observed as reaction products. Additionally, side reactions involving the solvent toluene, yielded benzaldehyde, benzyl alcohol and bibenzyl suggesting a degree of solvent oxidation occurred, potentially due to oxygen adsorbed on the catalyst during transfer to the reactor after ex-situ reduction. Esterification of stearic acid with benzyl alcohol and stearyl alcohol also took place, producing benzyl stearate and stearyl stearate, respectively. Stearyl alcohol was the major product (Fig. 3) irrespective of reaction time but selectivity decreased with increasing reaction time (83% @ 6 h vs 70% @ 48 h). Formation of octadecane (arising from the hydrogenation of stearyl alcohol) was only seen to occur to a very limited extent, thus indicating that Co is inherently selective towards alcohol formation. As stearyl alcohol selectivity decreased the selectivity of stearyl stearate increased (27% after 48 h). This suggests that as stearic acid conversion into stearyl alcohol plateaued, esterification became more pronounced Furthermore, as reaction time increased, selectivity to benzyl stearate reduced suggesting that as stearic acid was consumed, this ester was lost. It is interesting to note that stearic acid conversion appears slower when benzyl stearate selectivity is highest (i.e., 6–10 h reaction time). As benzyl stearate is lost there is a sharper increase in the amount of stearic acid that is consumed (i.e., compare 10 vs 15 h reaction time). From this it is inferred that benzyl stearate may compete with stearic acid for adsorption sites thus lowering its rate of consumption. 3.3 Influence of catalyst mass Studies were conducted to understand the influence of catalyst mass and explore the possibility of catalyst deactivation. To study the effect of catalyst mass, 500 mg of stearic acid was hydrogenated at 300 °C and 50 bar hydrogen pressure in the presence of varying amounts of 4% Co/Al2O3 for a fixed reaction time of 15 h. Results are presented in Table 2. At fixed reaction time, stearic acid conversion and product selectivity was influenced by the mass of catalyst used. Specifically, the conversion with 25 mg of catalyst only reached 33%, whereas 50 and 100 mg of catalyst allowed for 60% and 91% conversion, respectively. These findings confirm that the plateau in conversion observed in Fig. 3 was not as a result of an equilibrium limit. Similar results were noted in the hydroconversion of sunflower oil to fatty alcohols over a CuZn catalyst [50] as well as in other systems [24,51]. The use of larger amounts of catalyst also allowed for a greater understanding of how conversion influences product selectivity (see Table 2). High conversion produces slightly more octadecane than before (Fig. 3) confirming that this is a secondary product and that Co is inherently selective towards stearyl alcohol formation (maximum octadecane yield = 5%). Similarly, heptadecane was only detected at relatively high conversion - the yield of heptadecane increased from 2% to 4% as the overall conversion increased. In contrast, benzyl stearate was only detected with 25 mg catalyst (i.e., at low conversion). Similarly, stearyl stearate yield was seen to decrease with increasing stearic acid conversion. This makes sense given that both acid and alcohol are necessary in order to form the ester and this is therefore most likely to occur when the system becomes unable to consume further stearic acid (i.e., with 25 mg catalyst). Additional tests (see later) confirmed that stearyl stearate could also be hydrogenated to stearyl alcohol under the same conditions. Curiously, octadecanal was only observed at higher conversions which is not necessarily expected since the aldehyde is an expected intermediate in the conversion of stearic acid to stearyl alcohol. This may suggest that octadecanal is formed from a reversible reaction (i.e., from stearyl alcohol dehydrogenation). 3.4 Catalyst stability testing Section 3.3 demonstrated that high conversion of stearic acid was possible if sufficient catalyst mass was used. However, the question still remains why does conversion plateau with 25 mg catalyst? To understand this, the role of carbon deposition and possible metal leaching was explored. A stability test was conducted by collecting and reusing spent catalyst. Hydrogenation of stearic acid was again performed at 300 °C and 50 bar H2 in the presence of 50 mg 4% Co/Al2O3 for 15 h. After the first reaction, the same catalyst was employed for a second reaction cycle under otherwise identical conditions. The performance of the recycled catalyst after multiple reaction cycles is presented in Fig. 4. This Figure includes data for a used sample which was calcined at 500 °C under a flow of nitrogen/air for 5 h, followed by re-reduction at 400 °C under H2 for 4 h. The regeneration procedure was adapted from a previous study which investigated the deactivation behaviour of Co/Al2O3 in the hydrogenation of palm oil [26]. Fresh catalyst achieved close to 60% conversion with 92% selectivity to stearyl alcohol with only small amounts of heptadecane, octadecane and stearyl stearate detected. When the spent catalyst was reused without any treatment there was a significant drop in conversion from 60% to 32%. The decrease in activity suggested loss of active sites during the first reaction and/or transfer to the second reaction. The decrease in activity appeared to have relatively little impact on selectivity. More specifically, stearyl alcohol selectivity remained above 90%. When recycled a second time, catalyst activity decreased even further (down to 12%) although selectivity again remained similar. Overall, these findings are indicative of a gradual loss of active sites and this may be caused by strongly adsorbed compounds blocking surface active sites [52]. Indeed, a study where Co/Al2O3 was used for the hydrogenation of palm oil revealed that activity declined dramatically after 100 h use due to the formation of carbonaceous species and partial sintering of the metal. These carbonaceous compounds consisted of oxygenates including fatty acids, fatty alcohols and esters which adsorb strongly to the catalyst surface [26]. Other studies also confirmed that oxygenates adsorb strongly on the surface of catalyst but suggested fatty acids preferentially adsorbed over fatty alcohols due to a higher electronegativity of the carbonyl group [34]. Regeneration (i.e., calcination & re-reduction) of the spent catalyst allowed for partial recovery of catalyst performance (see Fig. 4). Conversion increased to 30% but with a small increase in stearyl alcohol selectivity relative to fresh catalyst (95% vs 92%). Thus, deactivation is likely to be associated with carbon retention/deposition and appropriate treatment can remove some of the carbonaceous deposits on the catalyst and partially recover the initial activity. To further investigate deactivation, both fresh and used (24 h use) 4% Co/Al2O3 catalyst were characterised by FTIR ( Fig. 5). No features appeared in the spectrum of the fresh catalyst whereas features identifiable as adsorbed CH-containing species were observed for the used sample. Intense peaks at 2850 and 2925 cm−1 were assigned to the symmetric and asymmetric CH2 stretching modes, respectively. A small peak at 2960 cm−1 was associated with the asymmetric CH3 stretching mode. Furthermore, the C-O stretching mode of carboxylates and deformation mode of O-H were represented by peaks at ca. 1600 and 1400 cm−1, respectively. The spectrum provides qualitative evidence that the compounds adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst are likely to be oxygenates. However, these may have originated from either stearic acid, stearyl alcohol or stearyl stearate as all contain long chain alkyl groups and carbonyl functions. Therefore, further quantitative analysis was undertaken. The relationship between peak area and alkyl chain length was studied by McNab et al. [40]. The investigation determined the absorption coefficients of the asymmetric stretching modes of CH3 and CH2 groups and that allowed for the average chain length of adsorbed species on the surface of alumina and Co/Al2O3 to be determined. Assuming linear species only (appropriate in this study), the average chain length for an adsorbed species can be calculated using the following expression: (8) CH 2 : CH 3 ( chain length ) = A CH 2 / A CH 3 CH 2 : CH 3 ( abs coeff ) Where the ratio of the absorption coefficients, CH2:CH3, was taken as 0.37 [40] and ACH2 and ACH3 are the integrated absorbances associated with the asymmetric CH2 (2928 cm−1) and CH3 (2960 cm−1) stretching modes (obtained by peak fitting). From the calculation, it was found that the chain length of the alkyl species was 18, thus confirming hydrocarbon retention is not associated with any oligomeric species. Instead, it would appear that shorter oxygenates such as stearic acid or stearyl alcohol were strongly adsorbed and may have contributed towards deactivation. Similar hydrocarbon retention phenomenon were reported as the main cause of deactivation of Re-Ni-Mo/γ-Al2O3 and MnCoO/AC catalysts for the deoxygenation of palm oil [53,54]. Further analysis was conducted to evaluate whether metal leaching also contributes towards deactivation. The presence of fatty acids under hydrogen pressure can lead to the formation of soaps which may facilitate metal leaching [2]. For example, stearic acid hydrogenation over Ni-MoOx/CeO2 resulted in leaching of both Ni and Mo [55]. Therefore, the amount of the metal in the fresh and used 4% Co/Al2O3 samples were analysed by MP-AES. The loading of cobalt in fresh and used materials were 4.04% and 3.80%, respectively. This suggests some loss of cobalt during the reaction, which may have contributed to the loss of activity during reaction cycles (Fig. 4). Note that any leached Co is not thought to be catalytically active because otherwise the plateau effect observed in Fig. 3 would not have been observed. 3.5 Influence of cobalt loading Next, the effect of cobalt loading on the hydrogenation of stearic acid was investigated over catalysts with 2–10 wt% Co ( Table 3). In the absence of cobalt, the parent alumina support was able to convert 3% of the stearic acid with 100% selectivity to benzyl stearate, thus indicating that the surface acidity is associated with ester formation (note: in this case only benzyl stearate is observed since stearyl alcohol formation is not possible). The 2% Co/Al2O3 sample exhibited the lowest activity attaining only 5% conversion with benzyl stearate as the only product detected (Table 3 – entry 2). The low cobalt loading and the corresponding difficulty in reduction for this sample likely generates very little of the active zero valent cobalt. Therefore, performance was similar to that of alumina alone. For samples with 4–10 wt% Co (Table 3 – entries 3–11), conversion generally rose in line with the cobalt loading although the differences between 6, 8 and 10 wt% loadings were small. For example, after three hours of reaction, the conversion for 6, 8 & 10 wt% Co were 17%, 23%, and 26%, respectively. However, these values were significantly higher than the 10% conversion obtained over 4% Co/Al2O3 after ten hours reaction. In addition to increasing conversion, higher amounts of cobalt progressively decreased the extent of ester formation allowing for 100% selectivity towards the desired stearyl alcohol product (Table 3 – entries 5, 7 and 9). This effect is thought to be associated with Co, at least in part, covering sites on the alumina surface which would otherwise facilitate ester formation (see later). In terms of selectivity, a useful comparison can be made by comparing Table 3 entries 4, 6, 8 & 10 as these rows represent the 4–10 wt% Co loadings but at a similar extent of conversion (i.e., close to iso-conversion points). The exceptional selectivity towards stearyl alcohol for higher loaded catalysts remained true even when the reaction times were extended and higher conversions achieved. The most striking example being 10% Co/Al2O3 which exhibited 100% alcohol selectivity at 65% conversion after 15 h of reaction time (Table 3 – Entry 11). Another interesting point to note was that over 6% Co/Al2O3 benzyl stearate was observed at short reaction times but this product disappeared at longer reaction times suggesting that the initial ester product could be hydrogenated. Stearyl alcohol selectivity was either high or perfect for cobalt loadings in the range 6–10 wt%. Selectivity was apparently not influenced within the relatively narrow range of dispersion/particle sizes present in these samples (5.0 – 7.3% dispersion, 13–19 nm particle size). Therefore, above a certain loading, additional cobalt primarily serves to improve activity by providing more zero valent metal sites and thus ensuring that the balance between metal/hydrogenation activity and acid sites/esterification activity was tipped in the favour of the former. Similar observations have been reported for the hydrogenation of stearic acid over ReOx/TiO2 [56] where a change in metal dispersion and particle size only effected the reaction rate/conversion without influencing the product selectivity. High selectivity to stearyl alcohol may in part, be related to the relative adsorption strength of the acid compared with the alcohol product. Indeed, competitive adsorption is reported as the main reason for the high selectivity of stearyl alcohol over alkanes [12,34,56]. However, the detection of octadecane over the 4% and 6% loaded samples at relatively low conversion (11–33%) suggests either the presence of specific sites for these samples which are absent at higher loadings, or, more likely, that hydrogenation of the ester provides a route to formation of the alkane with the ester being able to compete with the acid for adsorption sites. This will be discussed in more detail later. Table SI 1 provides a summary of different metal catalysts reported in literature for carboxylic acid hydrogenation. In general, there are formulations where performance exceeds that reported here for Co (i.e., lower reaction temperature/pressure and/or higher alcohol yield). However, in many cases, those formulations involve precious metals and it is desirable to be able to work with less expensive metals. In terms of non-precious metals there are some excellent results reported in literature already for Co, Cu and Ni catalysts (see Table SI 1). 3.6 Influence of acidity The acid–base properties of Co/Al2O3 samples were studied in order to correlate activity with surface acidity. More specifically, to confirm the link between support acidity and ester formation. The acidity of catalysts was investigated by pyridine adsorption monitored by FTIR [38,57–59]. Based on selectivity data (Table 3) the acidity investigation involved: the Al2O3 support, 2% Co/Al2O3 and 8% Co/Al2O3 samples which represented the range of ester formation capabilities. Band area due to pyridine adsorption was used along with Eq. (4) (see experimental) in order to calculate the number of micromoles adsorbed per gram of sample as presented in Table 4. The introduction of pyridine to the samples resulted in a series of bands in the IR spectrum (Fig. S2 in supporting information). An intense band at 1443 cm−1 associated with pyridine adsorption on Lewis acid sites is observed along with a weaker band at 1490 cm−1 - generally associated with a combination of pyridine adsorption on Lewis & Brønsted acid sites. Three further bands appeared at 1577, 1590 and 1610 cm−1 as a cluster. The peaks at 1577 cm−1 and 1610 are also associated with pyridine adsorption on Lewis acid sites. The band at 1590 cm−1 decreased more rapidly with outgassing and is therefore attributed to physisorbed pyridine. Importantly, the peak characteristic of adsorption on Brønsted acid sites at ca. 1540 cm−1 was not observed. This suggests that the surface is dominated by Lewis acidity and that the band at 1490 cm−1 is due entirely to adsorption at Lewis acid sites. By following the spectra as a function of evacuation temperature insight into acid site strength can be attained, with pyridine retained above 160 °C considered as being held by strongly acidic sites [34]. Table 4 summarises the amount of pyridine adsorbed at various stages of analysis (based on the 1450 cm−1 band). The parent alumina has the highest number of acid sites (213 µmol/g after room temperature evacuation). The number of acid sites decreased to 144 µmol/g and 63 µmol/g with the addition of 2 and 8 wt% cobalt. The same trend existed with respect to the pyridine retained after evacuation at 100 and 160 °C. The similarities in terms of numbers of acid sites for Al2O3 and 2% Co/Al2O3 after evacuation at 100 °C appears consistent with the similar selectivity towards benzyl stearate displayed by these two samples (Table 3 entries 1 and 2). As cobalt loading increases, fewer and fewer Lewis acid sites exist meaning that ester formation occurs less readily, thus explaining why stearyl alcohol selectivity reaches 100% for higher loaded samples. 3.7 Reaction pathway To further confirm the role of the alumina in product formation, an additional test was performed whereby the support was exposed to stearic acid in the presence of stearyl alcohol ( Table 5, entry 1). Under these conditions, 42% of stearic acid was converted to stearyl stearate (83% selectivity) and benzyl stearate (17% selectivity). Alumina is known to play a role in catalysing several side reactions during hydrodeoxygenation reactions with the Lewis acid sites being of the foremost importance. Ryymin et al. reported that alumina alone participates in the hydrotreating reaction [60] playing a role in the hydrogenation/dehydrogenation of methyl heptadecanoate to the corresponding carboxylic acid. Alumina is also reported to convert triglyceride containing palm oil into fatty acids and propane with 56% conversion without alkane product [21]. Other studies also mention that catalyst acidity impacted conversion and product selectivity during hydrogenation of oleic acid over Co-CoOx/Al2O3 and Ni-Fe/SiO2-ZrO2 catalysts [34,61]. Several other reactions were conducted to determine the key steps in the overall stearic acid hydrogenation mechanism (Table 5). Stearyl alcohol was observed to be the major product for all reactions and this should be produced through the hydrodeoxygenation route with octadecanal as an intermediate (Table 2 and Table 3). However, octadecanal was only found in trace amounts which suggests that the rate of octadecanal hydrogenation to form stearyl alcohol is relatively fast. One possibility is that octadecanal remains adsorbed on the catalyst and undergoes subsequent transformation to stearyl alcohol without leaving the surface [10,56,62]. In the absence of stearic acid, stearyl alcohol was hydrogenated to octadecane and heptadecane (Table 5, entry 2) which appears to confirm that stearic acid inhibits both over-hydrogenation and decarbonylation. In the absence of hydrogen, decarboxylation of stearic acid can occur to produce heptadecane (11% selectivity) but benzyl stearate is the main product (89% selectivity). Similarly, in the absence of hydrogen enhanced ester formation occurs when stearyl alcohol and stearic acid are both present (Table 5, entry 4). Finally, the use of stearyl stearate as starting reagent (Table 5, entry 5) confirmed that both stearyl alcohol and octadecane could be formed from ester hydrogenation. The relatively large amount of octadecane obtained here compared with that from stearic acid hydrogenation (Table 3) suggests that the ester itself may undergo direct hydrogenation to yield alkane rather than alkane being generated as a product of stearyl alcohol hydrogenation. It should be noted that whilst stearyl stearate can be converted into octadecane we don’t yet know how facile this step would be should the ester structure be different. On the basis of reactions performed, the reaction pathway presented in Scheme 2 is proposed for stearic acid hydrodeoxygenation. The first step is hydrogenation of stearic acid to form octadecanal as an intermediate which is rapidly converted into stearyl alcohol. Both of these steps require metallic Co sites to proceed. Alternatively, octadecanal can be converted to heptadecane via decarbonylation. However, reactions where stearyl alcohol was the reactant also generated heptadecane. Over-hydrogenation of stearyl alcohol can conceivably produce octadecane, although it is also possible to produce octadecane from hydrogenation of stearyl stearate. The latter forming under conditions where both stearic acid and stearyl alcohol co-exist and in the presence of Lewis acid sites. This scheme is generally consistent with other studies [8,56,62,63]. However, the hydrogenation of stearyl stearate to produce octadecane is less commonly reported. The production of an alkane from a waxy ester was first reported in the selective hydrogenation of oleic acid towards fatty alcohols over Ru-Sn-B/Al2O3 catalyst [64]. 4 Conclusion Stearyl alcohol was successfully produced via hydrogenation of stearic acid over a series of cobalt alumina catalysts where the selectivity was influenced by cobalt loading. Low loaded cobalt catalysts (which exhibited limited reduction to metallic cobalt) and the alumina support, promoted the formation of esters due to high availability of Lewis acid sites – the occurrence of this side reaction limited stearyl alcohol selectivity. Higher cobalt loadings covered some of the support surface, decreasing the number of Lewis acid sites whilst simultaneously increasing the number of available cobalt metal sites. The net result being a notably increase in stearyl alcohol selectivity to 100%. Whilst optimisation of the Co loading improves alcohol selectivity, catalysts were still subject to deactivation via oxygenate retention on the surface and a small amount of leaching. A simple calcination/reduction sequence does however, allow for at least partial recovery of catalytic activity. Given the availability and cost of Co relative to precious group metals, Co catalysts offer an alternative option for upgrading of naturally occurring fatty acids. coredata.dc:description: The selective hydrogenation of stearic acid to produce stearyl alcohol at 300 °C and 50 bar pressure was studied over a series of cobalt alumina catalysts with different cobalt loadings. Catalysts were prepared by wet impregnation and characterised by X-ray diffraction, H2 temperature programmed reduction, H2 chemisorption, N2 adsorption-desorption and Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy. Stearyl alcohol was observed to be the main reaction product, although heptadecane, octadecane and stearyl stearate were also produced in lesser amounts. The product selectivity was influenced by the availability of Lewis acid sites on the support which were found to be responsible for ester formation. Increasing the cobalt loading diminished the number of acid sites on the support surface whilst increasing the number of cobalt metal sites and thus enhanced the relative rate of hydrogenation leading to improved selectivity to stearyl alcohol.
